Subject: Re: Article Documenting How Natural Selection is Not Good at Choosing At Least One of Its Own Parameters (Mutation Rate)
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=54567749; y=T2CGiWsZY-KZyYjNWtjydr8K4SW90YNDuKTH0auNMULzqitDy7XV
X-Yahoo-Profile: kenstanley01

Jeff, 

Do you remember if I was advocating natural selection choosing its =
own
parameters?  I don't recall the specific discussion.  In any case,
ther=
e was a time when I thought evolution could be good at things like
that, bu=
t my mind has been changing in recent years, so I appreciate
what your pape=
r is saying.  

I think what caused me to become a skeptic about these kind=
s of
meta-evolutionary approaches is speaking to people who advocate the
id=
ea that evolution should "evolve its own encoding."  That idea is
connected=
 to evolvability, which suggests that evolution can figure
out its own best=
 parametrizations to become most effective at evolving
in a particular type=
 of domain.  Working on encodings started to make
me think that the search =
space of encodings is simply too vast to
expect evolution itself to optimiz=
e the encoding.  It is basically a
vast meta-search, far vaster than the pr=
oblem domain itself (which is
already vast to begin with in ambitious cases=
), and the actual problem
domain would seem to locally obfuscate the landsc=
ape of
meta-parameters (just as your results show).  

Overall, I started t=
o feel like human intuition is a better bet for
solving these meta-question=
s, or at least for addressing them
effectively.  Also, as we started to thi=
nk about novelty search, I
started to realize that evolution often innovate=
s *despite* selection
rather than because of it, which is even more complic=
ating at the
meta-level.  That is, at a meta-level like encodings, if somet=
hing
good came about, it might actually be because selection pressure was
l=
ow for a time.  In other words, if selection pressure has been high,
the st=
eps towards whatever optimal meta-parameter was found would
never have been=
 taken because the stepping stones are meta-suboptimal.
 Just talking about=
 this issue with all these "metas" reminds me why
it seems like wishful thi=
nking to rely on evolution to determine
everything.  Luck and happenstance =
have to be accepted as factors.

In another sense, evolving meta-parameters=
 optimally sounds
dangerously close to a free lunch.   If there is an algor=
ithm that can
evolve the right meta-parameters reliably, which in turn caus=
es it to
always find the right solution, when would that algorithm fail?

T=
he conclusion in my view is to trust our instincts.  We (humans)
still have=
 a role to play in setting the parameters of our algorithms
, and in design=
ing our encodings, by thinking about the problems they
are intended to solv=
e.  We are probably not going to get away with
offloading all the responsib=
ility on evolution itself, at least not if
you want to see it succeed in re=
asonable time.

By the way, Jeff (here I go contradicting myself), there ar=
e
reportedly evolutionary algorithms that seem to show that they benefit
fr=
om mutating mutation parameters.  Evolution Strategies come to mind.
 ES ha=
s done this kind of thing for years.  CMA-ES now uses
statistical technique=
s to predict optimal mutation distributions. 
What do your results suggest =
about such approaches?  Are they just
working on "toy problems" or is there=
 some explanation for why they
claim to derive benefit from evolving the pa=
rameters?

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@...> wrote:=

>
> Hello all-
> 
> A while back we had a discussion about whether natural=
 selection is
good at
> choosing its own parameters. Many people assume tha=
t it would be
beneficial
> to evolve the parameters of a run (e.g. mutation=
 rate, crossover rate,
> etc.). After having done some research in the area=
 I have concluded
that it
> does not work well.
> 
> When I expressed this =
view previously, some of you were very
skeptical. At
> that point, I promis=
ed to share a manuscript that investigates the issue
> once it was publishe=
d.
> 
> That manuscript finally came out yesterday in the journal PLoS
Comp=
utational
> Biology. I am rather excited because they chose it for the cove=
r of the
> September issue. 
> 
> You can see it here:
> www.ploscompbiol.o=
rg
> 
> Clune, et. al. =B3Natural Selection Fails to Optimize Mutation Rate=
s for
> Long-Term Adaptation on Rugged Fitness Landscapes.=B2
> 
> I am int=
erested to see what you think. In particular, I would like
to hear
> from t=
hose of you that were skeptical of my claim. Do you still feel
that
> evolu=
tion can manage itself in light of this work? Note: I recognize
that
> this=
 paper only covers mutation rates. However, the mutation rate is
one of
> t=
he most important parameters. Furthermore, I think similar issues will
> ar=
ise with other parameters that result in the perturbation of
genomes (e.g.
=
> crossover type and rate).
> 
> 
> PS. PLoS allows readers to rate article=
s. If you enjoyed the
article, and
> have a second, please rate it highly. =
I would really appreciate it!
> 
> PPS. If you are reading this email after=
 October 25th or so, here is a
> direct link to the article.
> 
> http://ww=
w.ploscompbiol.org/doi/pcbi.1000187
> 
> PPPS. I have another paper that fo=
und that evolving parameters did
not work
> tremendously well. That paper c=
overed more than just mutation rates.
You can
> check that out here:
> 
> h=
ttps://www.msu.edu/~jclune/publications/CluneEtAl-meta-GAs.pdf
> 
> 
> Chee=
rs,
> Jeff Clune
> 
> Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan State University
